title: DOWNLOAD DE ARQUIVOS
content:
Boa tarde! Uso o Mozilla para conectar meus sistemas de trabalho e nesses sistemas emito muitos relatórios (em PDF), os quais muitos são provisórios, ou seja, não preciso salvar na máquina, são apenas para visualização.

Ao utilizar agora, por exemplo, o WhatsApp Web no Mozilla, quando vou acessar um arquivo (um PDF por exemplo), NÃO dá mais a OPÇÃO, quando vou baixar um arquivo, ABRIR ou SALVAR (antes dava). E o pior: quando clico no arquivo sai da página do WhatsApp Web e fica apenas o arquivo que baixei e foi salvo sem eu querer.

Ou seja, antes era excelente, pois os arquivos que eu visualizava, NÃO sendo importante, apenas descartava. Agora tenho de salvar se eu quero apenas ver o arquivo enviado.

Teria como restabelecer a funcionalidade anterior?

title: Site-sensitive download locations
content:
Before version 98 of Firefox, it would remember where I downloaded files to based on what site I'm downloading the file from. For example: when I would download a statement PDF from American Express, the Firefox download prompt would automatically be navigated to <...documents\records\AmEx\statements>. Then, when I would go to download something like the latest Firefox installer, the download prompt would automatically start in the folder <...programs\standard programs\Firefox>. No navigation needed in either case. Now, with version 98, all Firefox can remember is the last place I downloaded to, with no memory of site context. (This includes sites I've been to more than once since the update to version 98.)

This was a very convenient, time-saving feature. Is there any way to restore this site-contextual memory of download directories?

(I tried searching through existing questions, but my apologies if I missed an existing question on this topic.)

Thank you!
creator: jdecker1

title: Firefox logo Can I disable "Downloads" pop-up window?
content:
Re: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/822640

The chosen solution does not work. The setting "browser.download.manager.showAlertOnComplete" doesn't exist, and adding it and setting it to false doesn't change the browser's behaviour.

title: Can't access Youtube when on Firefox
content:
Problem description: It's been 3 days since I can no longer access Youtube on Firefox on my macbook pro 13. I've been getting this monkey error saying "Oops, something went wrong." Please advise.

Variables: - I'm a user in China. - I'm on the latest version of Firefox (detailed info attached below). - My macOS is up to date (macOS Monterey, detailed info including hardware info given below). - I access Youtube via ExpressVPN (also up to date), as Youtube is still officially blocked in China. - Youtube is accessible on both Safari and Chrome browser on my macbook, with Firefox being the only exception (but Firefox is also my favorite and default browser, which is why I'm trying to fix this). - I've also tried accessing Youtube via Firefox on my windows 10 PC, and all is fine. All other variables remain the same. - All the above tests were done in the exact same internet (wifi) environment. - Conclusion: There's nothing wrong with the local internet, VPN service, or Youtube site. It could only be with either the current build of Firefox for mac, or some unknown settings on my macbook. I can't be certain which is it because I only have 1 macbook hence I can't reproduce or test on another.

My email address for contact: [email removed from public forum]. Looking forward to your prompt reply.

Cheers, Aaron
creator: multimixmeta
